title: Job Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 4.

questions.question: Who answered Job in Job Chapter 4?
options: Eliphaz the Temanite
Bildad the Shuhite
Zophar the Naamathite
Job himself
questions.correctAnswer: Eliphaz the Temanite
questions.explanation: Eliphaz the Temanite is the one who answered Job as stated in Job 4:1.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz ask if it will grieve Job in Job 4?
options: If they commune with him
If he loses his wealth
If he is forgotten
If he speaks truth
questions.correctAnswer: If they commune with him
questions.explanation: Eliphaz asks if Job will be grieved if they attempt to commune with him as mentioned in Job 4:2.

questions.question: According to Job 4:3, what has Job done for many?
options: Instructed many
Judged many
Punished many
Ignored many
questions.correctAnswer: Instructed many
questions.explanation: Job 4:3 states that Job has instructed many and strengthened the weak hands.

questions.question: According to Job 4:4, what has Job's words done?
options: Upheld him that was falling
Fallen on deaf ears
Caused confusion
Brought joy
questions.correctAnswer: Upheld him that was falling
questions.explanation: In Job 4:4, it is stated that Job's words have upheld him that was falling and strengthened feeble knees.

questions.question: What has now come upon Job, according to Job 4:5?
options: He faints and is troubled
He grows strong and joyful
He becomes wealthy
He travels to another land
questions.correctAnswer: He faints and is troubled
questions.explanation: Job 4:5 explains that now it has come upon Job, and he faints and is troubled.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz remind Job to remember in Job 4:7?
options: Who ever perished being innocent
How to pray
The days of his youth
The blessings of the land
questions.correctAnswer: Who ever perished being innocent
questions.explanation: Job 4:7 asks Job to remember who ever perished being innocent or where the righteous were cut off.

questions.question: What do those who plow iniquity and sow wickedness reap, according to Job 4:8?
options: The same
Blessings
Forgiveness
Peace
questions.correctAnswer: The same
questions.explanation: Job 4:8 states that those who plow iniquity and sow wickedness reap the same.

questions.question: By what means do the wicked perish according to Job 4:9?
options: By the blast of God and the breath of his nostrils
By the sword of man
By famine
By flood
questions.correctAnswer: By the blast of God and the breath of his nostrils
questions.explanation: Job 4:9 explains that by the blast of God they perish and by the breath of his nostrils are they consumed.

questions.question: What happens to the roaring lion and the fierce lion according to Job 4:10?
options: Their teeth are broken
They are victorious
They hunt successfully
They sleep
questions.correctAnswer: Their teeth are broken
questions.explanation: Job 4:10 states that the roaring lion and the fierce lion have their teeth broken.

questions.question: According to Job 4:11, what happens to the old lion?
options: It perishes for lack of prey
It becomes king of the beasts
It grows stronger
It finds shelter
questions.correctAnswer: It perishes for lack of prey
questions.explanation: Job 4:11 describes the old lion perishing for lack of prey and the scattering of the young lions.

questions.question: True or False: Eliphaz received a secret message in a vision during the night.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 4:12-13 describes Eliphaz receiving a secret message in a vision during the night.

questions.question: True or False: Eliphaz says mortal man can be more just than God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 4:17 asks rhetorically if mortal man shall be more just than God, implying that man cannot be more just than God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 4:20, the people perish forever without any regard.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 4:20 states that they perish forever without any regarding it.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Job 4:6: 'Is not this thy fear, thy confidence, thy hope, and the ______ of thy ways?'
options: uprightness
strength
wisdom
peace
questions.correctAnswer: uprightness
questions.explanation: Job 4:6 says: 'Is not this thy fear, thy confidence, thy hope, and the uprightness of thy ways?'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Job 4:16: 'It stood still, but I could not discern the form thereof: an image was before mine eyes, there was silence, and I heard a ______, saying,'
options: voice
sound
whisper
cry
questions.correctAnswer: voice
questions.explanation: Job 4:16 states that Eliphaz heard a voice saying after seeing an image.

medium.title: Job Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and feels faint and troubled. Based on Eliphaz's words in Job 4, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and faith?
options: Trials may come even to the upright, but they should not lose hope or confidence
Troubles always mean God has abandoned you
Only the wicked ever face suffering
Fainting and trouble are signs of spiritual failure
questions.correctAnswer: Trials may come even to the upright, but they should not lose hope or confidence
questions.explanation: Job 4:5-6 teaches that although trouble has come upon Job and he feels faint, his fear, confidence, hope, and uprightness remain important. Trials do not mean abandonment or failure but call for perseverance.

questions.question: How does Job 4:3-4 encourage believers in their role of supporting others?
options: Believers are called to strengthen the weak and uphold those who are falling
Believers should avoid involvement in others’ struggles
Only pastors have the responsibility to strengthen others
Helping others is optional and not commanded
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are called to strengthen the weak and uphold those who are falling
questions.explanation: Job 4:3-4 highlights how Job instructed many and strengthened weak hands, showing the biblical virtue of encouraging and supporting fellow believers in times of weakness.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz imply about the consequences of wickedness in Job 4:7-9, and how can this apply to our understanding of integrity and work ethic?
options: Those who sow wickedness will ultimately reap destruction, emphasizing the importance of honesty and integrity
Wickedness has no real consequences
Hard work regardless of character always leads to success
Integrity is secondary to outcomes
questions.correctAnswer: Those who sow wickedness will ultimately reap destruction, emphasizing the importance of honesty and integrity
questions.explanation: Eliphaz notes in Job 4:7-9 that the innocent do not perish, but those who commit iniquity reap the consequences, showing the biblical principle that integrity and righteousness lead to lasting benefit.

questions.question: A believer is fearful and trembling about their future. Based on Job 4:13-16, what spiritual discipline might help them find peace and trust in God?
options: Seeking God’s guidance through prayer and meditation on His word, even in fearful moments
Ignoring fears and pretending they do not exist
Relying solely on human wisdom without spiritual input
Avoiding reflection or spiritual discipline altogether
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking God’s guidance through prayer and meditation on His word, even in fearful moments
questions.explanation: Job 4:13-16 describes visions and fear coming in deep sleep, showing that spiritual experiences can bring conviction. Prayer and meditation help believers trust God amid uncertainty.

questions.question: What does Job 4:17 teach us about humility and our relationship with God?
options: Mortal man cannot be more just or pure than God, encouraging humility and trust in His justice
Humans are always more righteous than God
We can judge God’s actions by our standards
Pride in one’s own righteousness is encouraged
questions.correctAnswer: Mortal man cannot be more just or pure than God, encouraging humility and trust in His justice
questions.explanation: Job 4:17 reminds believers that no one is more just or pure than God, teaching humility and reliance on His perfect justice rather than self-righteousness.

questions.question: How does Job 4:18-19 inform our understanding of human frailty and the need for dependence on God?
options: Humans are fragile and prone to folly, so trusting in God rather than ourselves is essential
Humans are self-sufficient and need no help
Angels are more trustworthy than God
Human strength guarantees success
questions.correctAnswer: Humans are fragile and prone to folly, so trusting in God rather than ourselves is essential
questions.explanation: Job 4:18-19 contrasts God’s distrust of even His angels with human frailty (“houses of clay”), highlighting our dependence on God’s wisdom and grace.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel their efforts go unnoticed. According to Job 4:20-21, what biblical truth can encourage them about God’s perspective on human life and wisdom?
options: Though people perish daily, their worth and wisdom are recognized by God even if unseen by humans
Human life is meaningless and wisdom is futile
Only outward success matters to God
God ignores human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Though people perish daily, their worth and wisdom are recognized by God even if unseen by humans
questions.explanation: Job 4:20-21 acknowledges human mortality but also implies that wisdom and excellence are lost without regard, encouraging believers to trust God’s deeper recognition.

questions.question: How does Job 4:10-11 use the imagery of lions to teach about strength and vulnerability in life and faith?
options: Even the strong may face weakness and loss, teaching humility and perseverance
The strong will never fail or need help
Faith guarantees physical strength always
Vulnerability is a sign of spiritual failure
questions.correctAnswer: Even the strong may face weakness and loss, teaching humility and perseverance
questions.explanation: Job 4:10-11 compares lions losing their strength and prey, illustrating that all—even the mighty—experience hardship, urging humility and endurance in faith.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 4:7, Eliphaz teaches that the innocent never perish and the righteous are never cut off.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 4:7 explicitly asks who has ever perished being innocent or where the righteous were cut off, implying the innocent and righteous are preserved.

questions.question: True or False: Job 4:12-14 describes a terrifying vision that caused Eliphaz to tremble and fear deeply.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 4:12-14 recounts a vision in the night that brought fear and trembling upon Eliphaz, showing how divine revelation can impact the human spirit.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Job 4:2, Eliphaz asks if Job will be _____ if they attempt to speak with him.
options: grieved
angry
silent
joyful
questions.correctAnswer: grieved
questions.explanation: Job 4:2 records Eliphaz asking if Job will be grieved if they try to commune, highlighting the challenge of speaking truth in love during trials.

questions.question: How does Job 4:1-2 model the importance of speaking honestly with fellow believers during difficult times?
options: Eliphaz openly addresses Job despite potential grief, showing the value of honest and heartfelt communication
Eliphaz avoids speaking to Job to prevent conflict
Truth should be hidden to keep peace
Only silence is appropriate when others suffer
questions.correctAnswer: Eliphaz openly addresses Job despite potential grief, showing the value of honest and heartfelt communication
questions.explanation: Job 4:1-2 shows Eliphaz deciding to speak to Job honestly even if it might cause grief, demonstrating biblical encouragement for open, loving counsel.

questions.question: What does Job 4:8 teach about the principle of sowing and reaping in daily life and Christian stewardship?
options: Those who sow wickedness reap wickedness, emphasizing the need for righteous living and stewardship
Sowing has no effect on what one reaps
Only material wealth is reaped
Stewardship is unrelated to personal choices
questions.correctAnswer: Those who sow wickedness reap wickedness, emphasizing the need for righteous living and stewardship
questions.explanation: Job 4:8 states that those who plow iniquity and sow wickedness will reap the same, teaching a biblical principle of accountability and integrity in all actions.

questions.question: How does Job 4:6 encourage believers to examine their own faith and hope during hardship?
options: By reminding them to remember their fear, confidence, hope, and uprightness as foundations to endure trials
By telling them to abandon hope when suffering
By focusing only on external success
By ignoring personal faith
questions.correctAnswer: By reminding them to remember their fear, confidence, hope, and uprightness as foundations to endure trials
questions.explanation: Job 4:6 calls Job to remember his fear, confidence, hope, and uprightness, encouraging self-examination and spiritual grounding amid difficulties.

questions.question: What lesson can families learn from Job 4:11 regarding caring for the young and vulnerable?
options: Like lion’s whelps scattered when prey is lacking, children need care and provision to thrive
Children should be left to fend for themselves
Strength is only for adults, not children
Provision for the young is unimportant
questions.correctAnswer: Like lion’s whelps scattered when prey is lacking, children need care and provision to thrive
questions.explanation: Job 4:11 uses the image of lion’s whelps scattered due to lack of prey, instructing believers on the importance of nurturing and providing stability for children.

hard.title: Job Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 4.

questions.question: Who is the speaker addressing Job in Job Chapter 4?
options: Eliphaz the Temanite
Bildad the Shuhite
Zophar the Naamathite
Elihu the Buzite
questions.correctAnswer: Eliphaz the Temanite
questions.explanation: Eliphaz the Temanite is clearly identified as the speaker in Job 4:1, initiating the dialogue with Job.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Eliphaz use to challenge Job's willingness to listen in Job 4:2?
options: Wilt thou be grieved if we commune with thee?
Canst thou flee from God's judgment?
Is thy heart pure before the Lord?
Shall the righteous perish with the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Wilt thou be grieved if we commune with thee?
questions.explanation: In Job 4:2, Eliphaz asks if Job will be grieved by their speaking, implying a challenge to Job's openness.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz in Job 4:3-4, what had Job done for others before his current suffering?
options: Instructed many and strengthened the weak
Built altars and offered sacrifices
Led armies to victory
Prophesied to kings
questions.correctAnswer: Instructed many and strengthened the weak
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 describe how Job previously taught many and strengthened those who were weak, highlighting his former role as a helper.

questions.question: What theme is introduced in Job 4:7-8 regarding the fate of the innocent and the wicked?
options: The innocent do not perish, but the wicked reap what they sow
Both the innocent and wicked suffer equally
The innocent often face untimely death
The wicked are always rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: The innocent do not perish, but the wicked reap what they sow
questions.explanation: Eliphaz argues in Job 4:7-8 that innocence leads to survival, while those who commit iniquity reap destruction.

questions.question: What natural imagery does Eliphaz use in Job 4:10-11 to describe destruction?
options: The roaring and teeth of lions being broken
The floodwaters overwhelming the earth
The burning desert consuming the grass
The eagle soaring and then falling
questions.correctAnswer: The roaring and teeth of lions being broken
questions.explanation: Job 4:10-11 employs the imagery of lions losing their power and prey, symbolizing destruction and loss.

questions.question: In Job 4:12-17, Eliphaz recounts a vision he experienced. What effect did this vision have on him?
options: Fear and trembling causing all his bones to shake
Joy and enlightenment filling his heart
Confusion and doubt about God's justice
Anger and desire for vengeance
questions.correctAnswer: Fear and trembling causing all his bones to shake
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 15 describe Eliphaz's fearful reaction to the vision, emphasizing the seriousness of the message.

questions.question: What question does the voice in Eliphaz's vision pose about human righteousness in Job 4:17?
options: Shall mortal man be more just than God?
Can man create his own destiny?
Is the heart of man unknowable to God?
Will the wicked always prosper?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall mortal man be more just than God?
questions.explanation: Job 4:17 quotes the vision's voice questioning if man can surpass God's justice and purity.

questions.question: According to Job 4:18, what is God's attitude toward His servants and angels?
options: He puts no trust in them and charges them with folly
He rewards them generously for their faithfulness
He sends them to guide humanity
He hides His plans from them
questions.correctAnswer: He puts no trust in them and charges them with folly
questions.explanation: Verse 18 states that God does not fully trust His servants and angels, indicating divine sovereignty and human limitations.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Job 4:19 to describe humans in relation to their fragile nature?
options: Houses of clay with foundations in the dust
Trees planted by rivers of water
Stars that fade at dawn
Birds caught in a snare
questions.correctAnswer: Houses of clay with foundations in the dust
questions.explanation: Job 4:19 compares humans to fragile clay houses founded in dust, emphasizing mortality and vulnerability.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 4:20 states, 'They are destroyed from morning to evening: they perish forever without any ______.'
options: regarding it
repentance
hope
mercy
questions.correctAnswer: regarding it
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the unnoticed and continual destruction of humans, using the phrase 'without any regarding it'.

questions.question: What is the ultimate fate of humans described in Job 4:21?
options: They die without wisdom and their excellency goes away
They ascend to join the angels in heaven
They are reborn in a new form
They remain forever honored by God
questions.correctAnswer: They die without wisdom and their excellency goes away
questions.explanation: Verse 21 explains that human excellence fades and death comes even to the wise, underscoring human frailty.

questions.question: True or False: Eliphaz's speech in Job 4 primarily focuses on the theme of divine justice as retributive punishment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Throughout Job 4, Eliphaz argues that suffering is a consequence of sin, reflecting the retributive justice theme (Job 4:7-8).

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Job 4:10-11 when Eliphaz describes the lion and its prey?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Hyperbole
Personification
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Eliphaz uses metaphor to compare human destruction to the breaking of a lion's teeth and loss of prey (Job 4:10-11).

questions.question: How does Eliphaz’s vision in Job 4:12-17 foreshadow themes developed later in the book of Job?
options: It introduces divine skepticism about human righteousness
It promises Job immediate restoration
It condemns all human questioning of God
It reveals secret knowledge about Job’s innocence
questions.correctAnswer: It introduces divine skepticism about human righteousness
questions.explanation: The vision questions human purity versus God’s, foreshadowing ongoing debates about justice and righteousness (Job 4:17).

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme does Eliphaz’s argument in Job 4:7-9 most closely reflect?
options: The principle of retributive justice seen in Deuteronomy
The covenant promises to Abraham
The creation mandate in Genesis
The prophetic call for social justice
questions.correctAnswer: The principle of retributive justice seen in Deuteronomy
questions.explanation: Eliphaz reflects the retributive justice principle that the innocent prosper and the wicked perish, a theme prominent in Deuteronomy.

theological.title: Job Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who is the speaker addressing Job in this chapter?
options: Eliphaz the Temanite
Bildad the Shuhite
Zophar the Naamathite
Elihu the Buzite
questions.correctAnswer: Eliphaz the Temanite
questions.explanation: Eliphaz the Temanite is explicitly named as the speaker addressing Job in Job 4:1. This establishes the context of the dialogue, consistent with the roles of friends in Job 2:11 and 15:1.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz, what has Job done for others before his suffering?
options: Instructed many and strengthened weak hands
Accused the wicked and judged the unrighteous
Built houses for orphans and widows
Preached repentance to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Instructed many and strengthened weak hands
questions.explanation: Eliphaz praises Job for instructing many and strengthening weak hands in Job 4:3-4. This reflects Job’s prior role as a teacher and comforter, which aligns with Proverbs 31:8-9 and Isaiah 61:1-3 regarding uplifting the weak.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz imply is the cause of Job's current suffering?
options: It has come upon him because of fear and uprightness
It has come upon him due to his sin and wickedness
It is a test from God to prove his faith
It is due to the injustice of others
questions.correctAnswer: It has come upon him because of fear and uprightness
questions.explanation: Eliphaz ironically questions in Job 4:5-6 if Job’s fear, confidence, hope, and uprightness have led to his fainting and trouble, implying that suffering relates to one's life conduct. This reflects the Deuteronomic principle of retribution (Deut 28:15-68; Psalm 37:1-2).

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Eliphaz ask to challenge Job’s innocence?
options: Who ever perished being innocent? Or where were the righteous cut off?
Can the unclean be made clean? Can the sinner be justified?
Is the Lord unjust to forget your labor? Is your faith in vain?
Who can hide his sin before God? Who can escape His judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Who ever perished being innocent? Or where were the righteous cut off?
questions.explanation: Eliphaz asks in Job 4:7 whether anyone innocent has perished or the righteous been cut off, implying that Job’s suffering suggests guilt. This reflects a common Old Testament theme of divine justice (Psalm 34:19; Proverbs 11:31).

questions.question: According to Eliphaz, what is the fate of those who 'plow iniquity and sow wickedness'?
options: They reap the same and perish by the blast of God
They are forgiven when they repent
They prosper temporarily but fall finally
They are hidden from God’s judgment
questions.correctAnswer: They reap the same and perish by the blast of God
questions.explanation: Job 4:8-9 states that those who sow wickedness reap iniquity and perish by God's blast, illustrating the biblical doctrine of retributive justice (Galatians 6:7; Hosea 8:7).

questions.question: What imagery does Eliphaz use to describe the destruction of the wicked?
options: The roaring and teeth of lions are broken
The floodwaters sweep them away
Fire consumes their houses
Storms scatter their possessions
questions.correctAnswer: The roaring and teeth of lions are broken
questions.explanation: Eliphaz uses the imagery of lions losing their roar and teeth in Job 4:10-11 to depict the destruction of the wicked, symbolizing the loss of power and protection, similar to Isaiah 31:4-5 and Proverbs 28:1.

questions.question: What type of revelation does Eliphaz describe receiving in verses 12-16?
options: A vision in a dream with a fearful spirit
An audible prophecy from an angel
A direct encounter with God
A written message from a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: A vision in a dream with a fearful spirit
questions.explanation: In Job 4:12-16, Eliphaz recounts a nocturnal vision with trembling and a spirit passing before him, illustrating an example of a night vision or dream oracle, consistent with prophetic experiences like Daniel 7:1-2 and Joel 2:28.

questions.question: What question does the voice in Eliphaz's vision ask about human righteousness?
options: Shall mortal man be more just than God? Shall a man be more pure than his maker?
Can a man be holy without God's Spirit?
Is any man righteous before the Almighty?
Who can understand the thoughts of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall mortal man be more just than God? Shall a man be more pure than his maker?
questions.explanation: The voice in the vision questions human righteousness in Job 4:17, emphasizing God’s absolute holiness compared to human fallibility, aligned with Isaiah 64:6 and Romans 3:10.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz, how does God regard His servants and angels?
options: He puts no trust in His servants and charges angels with folly
He honors His servants and angels with wisdom
He punishes servants but rewards angels
He entrusts His servants and angels with great authority
questions.correctAnswer: He puts no trust in His servants and charges angels with folly
questions.explanation: Job 4:18 reveals that God does not fully trust even His celestial servants, highlighting God's sovereign authority and justice, comparable to Psalm 103:20-21 and Isaiah 40:13-14.

questions.question: What metaphor does Eliphaz use to describe human mortality in verses 19-21?
options: Houses of clay crushed before the moth
Grass that withers in the sun
A fading flower in the field
Dust that returns to the ground
questions.correctAnswer: Houses of clay crushed before the moth
questions.explanation: Eliphaz describes humans as houses of clay, fragile and transient, crushed before the moth in Job 4:19-21, symbolizing human frailty consistent with Genesis 3:19 and Psalm 90:5-6.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz imply about the wisdom of humans when they die?
options: They die even without wisdom
They gain wisdom after death
Their wisdom is preserved forever
Their wisdom judges others
questions.correctAnswer: They die even without wisdom
questions.explanation: In Job 4:21, Eliphaz states that people die without wisdom, underscoring human limitation and mortality, which is supported by Ecclesiastes 1:18 and Psalm 49:10-12.

questions.question: What theological doctrine is primarily illustrated by Eliphaz’s argument regarding suffering?
options: Retributive justice
Substitutionary atonement
Predestination
Sanctification
questions.correctAnswer: Retributive justice
questions.explanation: Eliphaz’s argument that suffering results from sin (Job 4:7-9) reflects the doctrine of retributive justice, where God rewards righteousness and punishes wickedness, a theme found in Deuteronomy 28 and Psalm 1.

questions.question: What does the presence of the fearful spirit and voice in Eliphaz's vision suggest about divine communication in the Old Testament?
options: God often uses dreams and visions to communicate
God only speaks through prophets in public
Divine communication is always audible and clear
God communicates directly without intermediaries
questions.correctAnswer: God often uses dreams and visions to communicate
questions.explanation: Job 4:12-16 illustrates that God uses dreams and visions to reveal truth, consistent with examples like Joseph’s dreams (Genesis 37:5-10) and Daniel’s visions (Daniel 7).

questions.question: How does Eliphaz’s speech in Job 4 contribute to Christian apologetics regarding suffering?
options: It upholds the justice of God in suffering
It denies any meaning to suffering
It claims all suffering is random
It teaches that suffering is always unjust
questions.correctAnswer: It upholds the justice of God in suffering
questions.explanation: Eliphaz argues that suffering is a consequence of sin and God’s justice (Job 4:7-9), a foundational apologetic point that God is just and righteous in trials, echoed in Romans 8:28 and James 1:2-4.

questions.question: What attribute of God is revealed by the phrase 'by the blast of God they perish'?
options: God’s sovereign power over life and death
God’s mercy towards sinners
God’s patience in judgment
God’s invisibility to humans
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign power over life and death
questions.explanation: Job 4:9 demonstrates God’s sovereign power to bring death by His breath, affirming divine omnipotence as in Psalm 33:6 and Isaiah 42:5.
